column1: '''Inglor Felagund''' was an older, rejected name for [[Finrod
column2: Finrod Felagund]]. It makes a relic appearance in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', in the form of "[[Gildor

column1: In earlier versions of the [[legendarium]], until the era of the first edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', the name "Finrod" was given to the character later known as [[Finarfin]]. [[Finrod
column2: Finrod Felagund]] was at the time known as Inglor Felagund.

column1: The name however was survived in the patronym ''Inglorion'' and perhaps in the Quenya form ''[[Ingalaurë]]''. The character with the name Inglorion in ''The Lord the Rings'' [[Gildor
column2: Gildor Inglorion]], although a fellow Noldo, was  unrelated to Finrod and certainly not his son. Finrod, as seen in ''[[The Silmarillion]]'', was unmarried and childless because his lover, Amarië of the Vanyar, did not follow him to Middle-earth.<ref>{{S

column1: Inglor in the early appearances was interpreted as "heart-gold" ([[Sundocarmë
Although the name Inglor(ion) is not analyzed in the later works, there is a similarity to Finarfin's [[Amilessë
column3: Shibboleth}}</ref>. Therefore according to the more recent background, Inglor could be the [[sindarization
column4: Sindarin interpretation]] of that name, having a new etymology and meaning ("Vanya-gold").
